I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The Government of Myanmar (GOM) has requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to help finance the Second Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Highway Modernization 
Project (the project).1 The project will support the construction of the 70 kilometer (km) arterial 
highway network connecting New Bago and Kyaikto, including a 4-lane bridge upon the 
Sittaung river. The new highway will (i) improve connectivity between Myanmar and Thailand 
by the deepening the east-west economic corridor (EWEC); (ii) support Myanmar’s economic 
development, regional economic growth, and international competitiveness by rehabilitating 
rural access roads; and (iii) promote more efficient and safer movement of goods and people 
between Bago and Kyaikto, reducing travel time by 50%.  
 
2.  Aside  from  the 70  km-highway,  other  project  outputs are  (i)  rural  access  roads 
completed: rehabilitation or upgrading of low-volume roads providing access to communities 
along the 70 km-highway; and (ii) enhanced capacity of the Ministry of Construction (MOC): 
for developing, financing, implementing and managing arterial highway projects, as well as for 
managing road safety. It is proposed that the project will be financed with an indicative amount 
of $250 million from concessional ordinary capital resources. The project, for approval in 2020, 
is  included  in  the  Country  Operations  and  Business  Plan:  Myanmar,  2019–2021.2 The 
feasibility study for the project is being prepared through an ADB TA to the GOM (TA 9314).3  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  As described in para 2, the ongoing TA 9314 is currently designing the ensuing project. 
Supplementing this TA 9314, the proposed transaction technical assistance (TRTA) will help 
the GOM develop a systematic and practical approach for road safety in the GMS EWEC 
Bago-Kyaikto existing national highway (90 km). In this process, the TRTA also will help GOM 
establish an initial foundation for a sustainable and systematic road safety regime, specifically 
with focus on enhancing MOC capacity for road safety. 4 Since TA 9314, which focuses on 
engineering aspects with respect to road safety design for the project, the TRTA will focus on 
providing road-user behavior based road safety measures.5  
 
4.  Myanmar suffers a loss of 1.5% of its gross domestic product annually due to road 
crashes. Based on the latest available road crash data (2013), Myanmar’s road fatality rate is 
the third worst in Southeast Asia, at 20 fatalities per 100,000 inhabitants, which doubled since 
2004. Nearly 60% of road casualties are softer modes: motorcyclists, cyclists, and pedestrians. 
Female road related fatalities account for 25 percent of the total.6 
 
5.  The behavior of road users needs to be changed to improve the situation through 
education on road safety issues and through strengthened enforcement of traffic regulations. 
While the government has not formulated a systematic policy response, several road safety 
initiatives have been undertaken with the support of ADB assistance. These include overview 
discussions on Myanmar’s road sector issues and opportunities, specific support for improving 
road network management and safety with focus on road environment, institutional aspects, 
                                                 
1  The proposed project was originally titled Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS): East-West Economic Corridor 
Highway Development Project. During the review of the COBP of 2018 (see footnote 2), the government 
requested the title change to Second Greater Mekong Subregion Highway Modernization Project. 
2  ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan: Myanmar, 2019–2021. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2017. Technical Assistance to the Republic of the Union of Myanmar for the Greater Mekong Subregion 
East–West Economic Corridor Highway Development Project. Manila. 
4  The proposed TRTA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 12 October 2018. 
5  Technical Assistance Report (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).  
6  World Health Organization: Global Status Report on Road Safety. 2013.

2 
crash  data  collection,  licensing,  and  road  worthiness  of  vehicles.7 However,  road  user 
behavior and related road safety issues have not been specifically addressed so far. 
 
6.   To establish a systematic policy response to address road user behavioral issues, the 
following measures have proven to be effective: (i) introduction of school curriculum on road 
safety;  (ii)  implementation  of  road  safety  programs  for  the  general  public;  (iii)  focused 
education in driving license schools; (iv) capacity development of police to properly enforce 
traffic rules and regulations; (v) adequate testing of vehicles worthiness; and (vi) funding.  
 
7.  Road user learning on road safety typically starts at the childhood level; first through 
parents, then continued in school. This road safety education becomes more solid when 
obtaining a driver’s license, ideally through a driving school’s systematic training. In the 
absence of such driving schools, systematic training, and loopholes in the licensing system 
allows  candidates  to  obtain  licenses  through  shortcuts.  Unfortunately,  this  applies  to 
enforcement personnel as well, who are currently implementing enforcement activities without 
appropriate capacity, on law, traffic engineering, and mannerly driving. 
 
8.  Further improvements are required on other aspects as well. As regards to road 
engineering, existing high-speed expressways are unsafe with no access control. National 
highways, with slower traffic speeds though, are similar in nature. All road users share the 
limited road space without proper segregation. Also, accuracy of road crash data, particularly 
those complied by the police, need significant improvement to support the effective formulation 
of road safety policies. According to the World Health Organization, about 70% of the crashes 
are unreported and are not included in the crash data compiled by the police. In addition, 
police crash data reporting sheets need to be streamlined to capture key information on cause 
of crash, and road environment data on crash sites.  
 
9.   Recognizing the imminent needs, the government has initiated to plan a solid road 
safety regime. 8 The National Road Safety Council (NRSC) was established in 2017 with the 
participation of all key relevant stakeholders including the MOC, Ministry of Transport and 
Communications (MOTC), National Police, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Health etc. At this 
initial stage, systematic support is required to ensure the efficient function of NRSC to address 
road safety issues in a sustainable manner. 
 
10.  The TRTA has been designed incorporating positive lessons learned from an ADB 
financed  project  in  Cambodia,  which  initiated  ADB’s  first  road  user  behavior  related 
assistance.9 Based on the proven success of this type of activity in improving road safety, the 
TRTA will extend its support to broader activities with the objective of establishing an initial 
foundation towards a sustainable road safety regime. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
11.  The project’s impact is aligned with an arterial highway network supporting economic 
development, regional economic growth, and international industrial competitiveness in a way 
that is safe, environmental-friendly and efficient. It is envisaged that the project will provide 
more efficient and safer movement of goods and people between Bago and Kyaikto, along the 
GMS EWEC. The TRTA intends to contribute to this outcome by establishing an initial 
foundation for a systematic approach to remedy road safety issues in Myanmar. The outputs 
of the TRTA aim to remedy behavior-related problems in a systematic manner. It is expected 
that the success of the TRTA will lead to the replication of similar activities along other arterial 
                                                 
7  ADB. 2017. Technical Assistance to the Republic of the Union of Myanmar for Improving Road Network 
Management and Safety, Manila (TA 8987-MYA). 
8  ADB. 2016. Myanmar Transport Sector Policy Note: Road Safety. Manila. 
9  ADB. 2010. Rural Roads Improvement Project, Manila (Loan 2670-CAM); and ADB. 2015. Rural Roads 
Improvement Project II. Manila (Loan 3151-CAM).

3 
highway networks in Myanmar, to contribute to the intended impact which the ensuing loan 
project is aligned with. 
 
12.  Output  1:  Road  safety  approach  for  existing  Bago-Kyaikto  road  section 
established. The TRTA will develop a sustainable road safety framework with completion of 
two deliverables: development of a safe school zone (SSZ) strategy, and development of a 
social enforcement system. The activities will be conducted on the existing Bago-Kyaikto road. 
This 90-km road section is mostly a two-lane national highway, with a diversity of road users: 
passenger cars, motorcycles, bicycles, 3-wheelers, animal driven carts, trucks, intercity buses, 
farm vehicles, pedestrians, and animals. Most rural areas along the road are farms with 
occasional restaurants, monasteries, and schools. Each town area along the road stretches 
usually  less  than  500  meters  with  markets,  restaurants,  government  offices,  residential 
buildings, and commercial buildings.  
 
13.  The  TRTA  will  reinforce  and  compliment  TA  9314  by  providing  inputs  to  the 
engineering design to improve road safety. For example, the TRTA will identify low cost 
engineering measures including, but not limited to traffic separation and traffic calming 
measures, to improve road safety for the Bago-Kyaikto new alignment. In addition, the TRTA 
will develop a complementary road safety program to be implemented over the life of the 
project. This program will be informed by stakeholder consensus building and education to 
develop a community-based road safety program, including a social enforcement system, and 
SSZs for Bago-Kyaikto existing road. 
 
14.  The TRTA will engage experts to build consensus among all stakeholder groups 
(community leaders, police, men and women, girls and boys in the communities). It will adopt 
a targeted approach for the awareness-raising and education activities on road safety. This 
approach will consider gender differences, with interventions being tailor-made for different 
groups (including targeting drivers on safe and responsible driving behavior). 
 
15.  It is expected that women and girls will actively participate in the activities as key 
stakeholders which include students, teachers (during and after school time) and families. It 
is expected that prominent participants will be mothers of students who are usually involved 
in SSZ implementation as is the case in developed countries. The role of fathers in SSZ will 
also be explored in this TRTA. To ensure the active participation of women in the TRTA as 
invaluable stakeholders, particular attention will be paid to avoiding additional burdens on 
women through careful meeting arrangements at times and venues convenient for their 
participation. 
 
16.  Output  2:  Government’s  capacity  to  collect  and  analyze  road  safety  data 
improved. This output will be achieved by preparing and implementing interim and long-term 
measures to improve the collection and analysis of road crash data. Based on the findings of 
this assessment, capacity building activities will be designed and provided to the Police. To 
begin, crash data along existing Bago-Kyaikto road will be cross-checked with hospital and 
clinic data for crash casualties/injuries to increase the accuracy of reported police data, the 
Ministry of Construction, the Ministry of Transport and Communication, Ministry of Health, and 
local governments. These activities will also include compilation of sex aggregated data 
wherever  relevant  for  better  planning.  Long-term  measures  will  include  comprehensive 
training program for concerned officials with advice for improving IT systems.  
 
17.  Output 3: Police capacity for traffic enforcement enhanced. This output will be 
achieved  by  providing  training  on  appropriate,  simple,  and  effective  enforcement 
methodologies to enforce traffic rules and regulations. The TRTA will develop a program to 
both improve the driving skills of police, and to enhance their ability to implement simple but 
effective enforcement techniques, so they can strengthen their enforcement activities.

4 
18.  The  TRTA  will  fund  an  international  training  program,  in  Japan,  which  will  be 
subsequently localized and replicated within Myanmar. To begin, participants (from MOTC, 
MOC, and the National Police) will travel to Japan for a focused training program on road 
safety. This program will cover Japan’s approach and historical context to road safety, and will 
incorporate field visits to police stations, expressways and national highways and associated 
safety features, driver learning schools, and SSZs. The TA will provide experts who will 
replicate the training locally in Yagon, Nay Pyi Taw and Mandalay with a train-the-trainer (TOT) 
activities. 
 
19.  Output 4: Road safety advisory support established. This output, the TRTA will 
prepare and disseminate materials for: (i) road safety information campaigns; (ii) safety during 
construction guidelines; (iii) innovative approaches and general guidelines for urban road 
safety enforcement; (iv) general guidelines for simulations and dry runs; (v) affordable low-
cost solution for safety engineering; (vi) guidelines for first aid and other response, and post-
crash  victims  support  guidelines,  and  (vii)  NRSC  capacity  enhancement.  Pamphlets, 
information  education  communication  (IEC)  materials,  and  flyers  will  be  prepared  with 
effective illustrations for deepening road safety advocacy under this output. All guidelines and 
materials will be simplified documents with a maximum of 3 pages, with colored illustrations 
designed for easy comprehension and reference, and to be TOT friendly. 
 
20.  All communication materials to be developed under this output (and other outputs of 
the TRTA) will be targeted and tailor-made for the different stakeholder groups. Such materials 
shall be gender sensitive (no gender stereotypes in content and images) and be based on sex 
disaggregated analysis and gender related information on behavior and risk. Also, all reports, 
IEC materials, flyers, and manuals produced under the proposed TRTA will receive the 
endorsement of all related government entities prior to finalization. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
21.  The TRTA is estimated to cost $1,055,950, of which $999,950 will be financed on a 
grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR). The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 2.  
 
22.  The GOM will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, their 
remuneration, per diem, and office accommodation for the TRTA implementation. The GOM 
was informed that approval of the TRTA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
23.  ADB  will  administer  the  TRTA  through  Southeast  Asia  Regional  Department’s 
Transport and Communications Division (SETC). SETC will select, supervise, and evaluate 
consultants, organize workshops; and provide staff to act as the resource persons in the 
workshops. 
 
24.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table below.

Economic Corridor

5

financing

ADB=Asian Development Bank; QBS=quality-based selection; SERD = Southeast Asia Regional Department; 
SETC=Southeast Asia Transport and Communications Division; TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
25.  Consulting services. It is proposed that the consulting services contract be a lump 
sum contract. It is expected that the consultants will engage service providers for surveys, and 
for overseas training activities (in Japan, but replicated in Myanmar as well, with TOT 
approach) as required. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the ADB 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions.10 
 
26.  Cofinancier requirements. The TRTA will be financed by JFPR. 
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
29.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $999,950 to GOM to be 
financed on a grant basis by the JFPR for Road Safety for Highway Development in Greater 
Mekong Subregion East-West Economic Corridor, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
                                                 
10 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).
